methodology: For each hurricane event, determined the UTC landfall time from metadata, computed FHR at landfall for the current init cycle, and evaluated whether a different cycle would place landfall at a lower FHR while preserving sufficient pre-landfall approach and post-landfall coverage. All 15 events use synoptic cycles (00/06/12/18z) which provide F48 max range — critical for hurricanes with extended inland impacts. Landfall FHRs range F07-F12, which is ideal: low enough for fresh mesoscale data, high enough for 5-10 hours of approach buildup.

events.name: Hurricane Laura Cat 4
events.rationale: 18z synoptic cycle places Cat 4 landfall (0600 UTC) at F12 — ideal balance. F00-F11 capture the entire Gulf approach with RI (Cat 1 to Cat 4 in prior 24h), F12 is the dramatic eyewall-at-coast moment, and F13-F18+ capture post-landfall inland wind damage through Lake Charles. Synoptic cycle provides F48 max if needed for extended tracking. A 20z init would place landfall at F10 but is non-synoptic (F18 max) and only gains 2 hours of freshness.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 00z Aug 27 init places landfall at F06 — freshest possible data for the eyewall crossing. Captures landfall and post-landfall inland wind damage through Lake Charles at F06-F18. Misses most of the Gulf approach though. Good secondary for post-landfall focus.

events.name: Hurricane Sally Cat 2
events.rationale: 00z synoptic cycle places Sally's landfall at Gulf Shores at F10 — excellent. Sally's defining feature was extreme slowness (<5 mph), so extended FHR coverage is critical to capture the stalled rainfall. Synoptic cycle gives F48 max, allowing coverage of the prolonged 30-inch rainfall event through F24-F48. F00-F09 show the stalled approach, F10 is landfall, F11-F18+ capture the catastrophic inland flooding in Pensacola and Escambia River basin.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 06z synoptic init captures the ongoing stalled rainfall after landfall (now at F04 for landfall). Best for the post-landfall inland flooding phase (F04-F48), especially the record Escambia River flooding.

events.name: Hurricane Delta Cat 2
events.rationale: 12z synoptic cycle places Delta's Creole, LA landfall at F11. Compound event (12 miles east of Laura's landfall 6 weeks prior) with good approach window F00-F10 showing the weakening from Cat 3 to Cat 2 over Laura's cold wake. Post-landfall F12-F18+ captures inland impact into already-devastated Lake Charles. Synoptic F48 max provides extended tracking.

events.name: Hurricane Zeta Cat 3
events.rationale: 12z synoptic cycle places Zeta's Cocodrie, LA landfall at F09 — ideal for this fast-mover (~25 mph). At 25 mph forward speed, Zeta crossed the entire Gulf Coast in under 12 hours, so the post-landfall inland wind track through MS and AL (F10-F18) is critical. F09 for landfall gives 9 hours of Gulf approach and then captures the fast inland traverse causing 2.6M power outages across SE states.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 18z synoptic init captures post-landfall inland traverse at F03+ through MS/AL/GA. Best for studying the fast-moving inland wind damage pattern. Zeta at F03 = midnight Oct 28 central MS.

events.name: Tropical Storm Eta
events.rationale: 18z synoptic cycle places Eta's Keys crossing at F10. Good approach from Caribbean through Florida Straits (F00-F09), Keys crossing (F10), and post-crossing flooding of South Florida (F11-F18+). Synoptic F48 max is valuable because Eta had a complex looping track with a second FL landfall at Cedar Key 3 days later (too far for HRRR to capture, but the initial South Florida flooding is well-covered).

events.name: Hurricane Ida Cat 4
events.rationale: 06z synoptic cycle places Ida's Port Fourchon landfall at F11. F00-F10 capture the final approach with rapid intensification over the Loop Current (65 mph gain in 24h). The Cat 4 eyewall structure at F08-F11 is the money shot. Post-landfall F12-F18+ tracks inland devastation through SE Louisiana. Synoptic F48 max allows tracking remnants into the Tennessee Valley. Landfall on Katrina's 16th anniversary.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 12z synoptic init captures the post-landfall inland phase (landfall at F05). Best for studying the inland wind field decay and continued LA devastation. Also provides F48 range for tracking remnants toward the Northeast.

events.name: Hurricane Nicholas Cat 1
events.rationale: 18z synoptic cycle places Nicholas's Matagorda Peninsula landfall at F11.5 (~F12). Primarily a heavy rain event (6-15 inches Houston metro), so extended post-landfall coverage through F18-F48 is critical to capture the stalled remnant circulation producing ongoing flooding. F00-F11 show the western Gulf approach with slow movement, F12 is landfall, F13-F24+ capture the stalled post-landfall rain over SE Texas and Louisiana.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 00z Sep 14 synoptic init places landfall at F05.5 — captures the immediate post-landfall stalled rain over Houston (F06-F48). Best for the prolonged inland flooding phase that was the primary impact.

events.name: Hurricane Ian Cat 4
events.rationale: 12z synoptic cycle places Ian's Cayo Costa landfall at F07 — the lowest landfall FHR in the hurricane set, and perfectly appropriate for this event. Cat 5 peak intensity (160 mph) at ~17-18 UTC = F05-F06 is captured just offshore, with landfall at F07. The brief Cat 5 -> Cat 4 weakening offshore is one of the most dramatic sequences in the dataset. F00-F06 show the approach with peak intensity, F07-F12 capture landfall and cross-FL traverse, F13-F18+ track into the Atlantic for the SC second landfall.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 18z synoptic init captures Ian crossing FL peninsula (landfall at F01). Best for post-landfall inland flooding, cross-peninsula traverse, and emergence into the Atlantic. However, F01 for landfall provides almost no approach context.

events.name: Hurricane Nicole Cat 1
events.rationale: 00z synoptic cycle places Nicole's Vero Beach landfall at F08 — ideal. Nicole's key feature was its enormous wind field (TS winds 450+ miles from center), so the approach from the Atlantic (F00-F07) captures this structure beautifully. F08 landfall, F09-F18+ show the broad wind field crossing FL and the associated beach erosion. Compound impact event (striking same areas Ian devastated 6 weeks earlier).

events.name: Hurricane Idalia Cat 3
events.rationale: 00z synoptic cycle places Idalia's Keaton Beach landfall at F12. Crucially, Idalia's Cat 4 peak (130 mph) occurred at ~0800-0900 UTC = F08-F09, so this cycle captures the rapid intensification peak AND the slightly weakened Cat 3 landfall. F00-F07 show the eastern Gulf approach with explosive RI (75 mph to 130 mph in 24h over 88F SSTs). F08-F09 is the brief Cat 4 peak. F10-F12 is the slight weakening to Cat 3 over the shallow Big Bend shelf. F13-F18 captures inland traverse into Georgia.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 06z synoptic init places landfall at F06 — freshest possible data for the Big Bend impact. Captures landfall at F06, post-landfall through GA at F07-F18. Misses the RI and Cat 4 peak though, which is the most dramatic part of the story.

events.name: Hurricane Lee Post-Tropical
events.landfall_utc: 2000 UTC September 16, 2023 (Nova Scotia); closest Maine approach ~1600-1800 UTC
events.rationale: 06z synoptic cycle captures Lee's extratropical transition and Maine impacts across F06-F14. Since Lee did not make US landfall, the relevant window is the closest Maine approach (1600-1800 UTC = F10-F12) and the broader wind field impacts (1200-2000 UTC = F06-F14). The structural transition from tropical to extratropical is the key scientific feature — this cycle captures the full evolution. A later init would miss the pre-transition structure.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 12z synoptic init captures peak Maine impacts at F04-F06 with freshest data. Best for wind field analysis at closest approach. Misses the earlier ET transition phases though.

events.name: Hurricane Beryl Cat 1
events.rationale: 00z synoptic cycle places Beryl's Matagorda, TX landfall at F09. The historic former Cat 5 (earliest ever Atlantic) re-intensifying to Cat 1 in the Gulf. F00-F08 capture the western Gulf approach with partial re-intensification, F09 is landfall, F10-F18+ capture the devastating inland impacts (2.7M power outages during deadly heat wave, 10-15 inch rainfall across Houston metro).

secondary_cycles.rationale: 06z synoptic init places landfall at F03 — captures immediate post-landfall Houston impacts (F03-F48). Best for studying the prolonged power outage and heat-wave compound disaster, but misses almost all approach.

events.name: Hurricane Debby Cat 1
events.rationale: 00z synoptic cycle places Debby's Steinhatchee, FL landfall at F11. Debby is a slow-mover like Sally — the FL landfall is just the first chapter. After landfall, the remnant stalled over the SE coast for 3+ days producing 20-30 inches in SC. The synoptic F48 max is essential to capture the initial landfall (F11) AND the beginning of the stalled rainfall pattern (F12-F48). F00-F10 show the eastern Gulf approach, F11 is Big Bend landfall, F12-F48 begin the slow drift toward SC.

secondary_cycles.rationale: Separate cycle 24 hours later captures the stalled SC rainfall phase. Debby's remnants are drifting over the warm SW Atlantic and training extreme rain bands over Charleston. This is effectively a separate event from the FL landfall.
Another separate cycle for the SC second landfall at Bulls Bay (~0545 UTC Aug 8 = F18). Captures the peak SC flooding as Debby finally moves onshore again.

events.name: Hurricane Helene Cat 4
events.rationale: 18z synoptic cycle places Helene's Big Bend FL landfall at F09. CRITICALLY, the synoptic F48 max is essential here because Helene's most catastrophic impacts — the civilization-altering WNC mountain flooding — peaked 6-18 hours AFTER landfall (F15-F27). The 20-30 inch rainfall over the southern Appalachians, 1,400 landslides, and historic Asheville flooding occurred roughly F15-F30. No other cycle captures both the dramatic Cat 4 FL landfall AND the inland mountain catastrophe. F00-F08 show the fast Gulf approach, F09 is the 140 mph Big Bend landfall, F10-F14 show rapid inland traverse through GA, F15-F24+ capture the orographic rainfall disaster in WNC. Essential FHRs must extend to F30+ for this event.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 00z Sep 27 synoptic init is 3 hours after landfall. Freshest data for the inland traverse and WNC mountain catastrophe. Landfall already occurred (F00 = 3h post-landfall). WNC peak flooding at F06-F18. Essential companion cycle for the inland disaster.

06z Sep 27 synoptic init is 9 hours after landfall, right at the start of peak WNC flooding (F00). WNC peak at F00-F12. Freshest mesoscale data for the mountain flooding peak. Best for studying the orographic enhancement mechanism.

events.name: Hurricane Milton Cat 3
events.rationale: 12z synoptic cycle places Milton's Siesta Key landfall at F12.5 (~F13). This is slightly higher FHR than ideal, but the tradeoff is essential: the historic tornado outbreak (46+ tornadoes) occurred F06-F12 (1800-0000 UTC Oct 9), BEFORE landfall. This cycle captures both the tornado outbreak on the FL east coast AND the landfall. F00-F05 show the Gulf approach, F06-F12 capture the unprecedented tornado outbreak ahead of the storm (the most tornadoes ever from a landfalling hurricane), and F13 is the Cat 3 landfall at Siesta Key. F14-F18+ track the fast cross-FL traverse and Atlantic exit. An earlier init would miss the late-afternoon tornado outbreak entirely.

secondary_cycles.rationale: 18z synoptic init places landfall at F06.5 — fresher data for the landfall and post-landfall phase. Captures the tornado outbreak in assimilated data (F00 = 18z is the start of the outbreak). Best for the landfall/surge focus. Misses the Gulf approach though.
